column4: things didn't go too well. I'm not on a Live USB. I can't boot into either Windows or Ubuntu now.
is there a way to 'undo' the MBR commands I issued?
by perhaps mounting the file sytem and chrooting into it?
http://grub.enbug.org/Grub2LiveCdInstallGuide
how I identify my boot partition from the fdisk -l list?
the one with an asterisk in the boot column?
I cannot mount the boot partition. It's also the partition containing Windows. I receive an error when mounting.
You don't have a separate /boot partition.
ah. Thanks.
You're welcome.
I encounter a problem with "sudo chroot /mnt" - chroot: cannot run command `/bin/bash': No such file or directory
Then you mounted the wrong partition.
spot on. I mounted dev/sda2 rather than dev/sda7.
sudo umount /dev/sda2 causes a device is busy error.
similarly does "sudo umount /mnt"
fuser /mnt/ to see what process is using files on that filesystem.
no ouput.
I gave up trying to umount /mnt and mounted the actual partition (/dev/sda7) to /mnt1. Again I issued "sudo chroot /mnt1" and received the same 'bin/bash' error.
If the partition doesn't have /bin/bash then it's not the partition you want.
http://pastebin.com/H5Ktn9PF
I have tried /dev/sda2 and /dev/sda7. Where else could it be?
I don't know, sorry. I'm going to sleep now.
